entity_description: Divine being invoked to tell the story of the ingenious hero who travelled far and wide after sacking Troy
Famous town that was sacked by the ingenious hero
Sun-god whose cattle were eaten by the hero's men, leading to their destruction
Father deity, referred to as the father of the Muse
Ingenious hero who travelled far and wide after sacking Troy, trying to return home to his wife and country
Goddess who detained Ulysses in a large cave and wanted to marry him
The homeland where the hero is destined to return after years of wandering
God who persecuted the hero without ceasing and would not let him get home, later went to the Ethiopians for a festival
People at the world's end who lie in two halves, one looking West and the other East, who received Neptune for a festival
Sire of gods and men who spoke first when the gods met in his house, also called the father of gods
Man who made love to Agamemnon's wife unrighteously and killed Agamemnon, later killed by Orestes
Man who was killed by Aegisthus, father of Orestes
Son of Agamemnon who killed Aegisthus in revenge for his father's murder
Divine messenger sent by Jove to warn Aegisthus not to kill Agamemnon or make love to his wife
Son who would take revenge on Aegisthus when he grew up and wanted to return home
Goddess who speaks to her father Jove about Ulysses' sufferings, daughter of Saturn
Father of Minerva, also called King of kings
Man who was warned by Mercury but didn't listen and paid for everything in full
Suffering hero trapped on a lonely sea-girt island, far from friends, whom Minerva's heart bleeds for
Magician who looks after the bottom of the ocean and carries the great columns that keep heaven and earth asunder
Goddess who lives on the forested island in the middle of the sea and holds Ulysses captive, trying to make him forget his home through blandishments
Capable man who made burnt sacrifices to the gods before Troy, now tired of life and longing to see the smoke of his own chimneys, being tormented by Neptune
Place where Ulysses made many burnt sacrifices to propitiate the gods
Father god who speaks with Minerva about Ulysses, acknowledges Ulysses as the most capable man on earth and most liberal in offerings to immortal gods
God who is still furious with Ulysses for blinding Polyphemus, torments Ulysses by preventing him from getting home but will not kill him outright
King of the Cyclopes who had his eye blinded by Ulysses, son of Neptune and the nymph Thoosa
Race of beings ruled by Polyphemus as their king
Nymph who is the mother of Polyphemus and daughter of the sea-king Phorcys
Sea-king who is the father of Thoosa and grandfather of Polyphemus
Goddess who speaks with her father Jove about helping Ulysses return home
Goddess who speaks to her father Saturn, plans to help Ulysses by sending Mercury to Calypso and going to Ithaca to help Telemachus, wears golden sandals and carries a bronze-shod spear
Father of Minerva, referred to as King of kings
Hero who should get home according to the gods' decision, father of Telemachus
Divine messenger who will be sent to the Ogygian island to tell Calypso about the gods' decision regarding Ulysses
Island where Calypso resides and where Mercury will be sent
Goddess who will be told by Mercury that Ulysses is to return home
Destination where Minerva will go to help Telemachus, homeland of Ulysses
Son of Ulysses whom Minerva will embolden to call the Achaeans in assembly and speak to his mother's suitors
People whom Telemachus will call in assembly
Mother of Telemachus and wife of Ulysses, whose suitors are eating up sheep and oxen
Place where Minerva will conduct Telemachus to seek news of his father
Place where Minerva will conduct Telemachus to seek news of his father
Glittering imperishable sandals worn by Minerva that allow her to fly like wind over land or sea
Redoubtable, stout, sturdy and strong spear wielded by Minerva to quell ranks of heroes who displease her
Mountain with topmost summits from which Minerva darted down to Ithaca
Location where Minerva arrives at the gateway of Ulysses' house
Owner of the house where the suitors are gathered, brave father of Telemachus who is away
Goddess who disguises herself as Mentes, chief of the Taphians, and holds a bronze spear
Chief of the Taphians whom Minerva disguises herself as when visiting
People whose chief is Mentes, the identity Minerva assumes
Spear held by Minerva in her disguise as Mentes
Lordly men seated on hides of oxen they killed and eaten, playing draughts in front of Ulysses' house
Son of Ulysses who sits moodily among the suitors, thinking about his brave father, and welcomes the disguised Minerva
Goddess who is welcomed as a guest and follows Telemachus into the house where she is given a decorated seat
Host who welcomes the disguised Minerva, leads her into the house, takes her spear, and provides her with a seat and hospitality
Weapon carried by Minerva that Telemachus takes and places in the spear-stand
Stand against a strong bearing-post where Telemachus places Minerva's spear along with his father's many spears
Unhappy father of Telemachus whose many spears are kept in the spear-stand
Noisy and insolent group that Telemachus wants to keep Minerva away from while eating
Female servant who brings water in a golden ewer and pours it into a silver basin for hand washing
Beautiful golden vessel used by the maid servant to bring water
Silver container into which water is poured for hand washing
Higher-ranking servant who brings bread and offers good things from the house
Servant who fetches plates of various meats and sets golden cups
Group of men who take their places on benches and seats, eat and drink, then want music and dancing as embellishments of their banquet
Male servant who brings wine and pours it out for the guests
Male servants who pour water over the suitors' hands
Female servants who go round with bread-baskets
Young servants who fill the mixing-bowls with wine and water
Singer who is compelled by the suitors to sing to them, plays the lyre
Musical instrument brought by a servant to Phemius and used for singing
Young man who speaks low to Minerva about the singing and the cost of the banquet
Goddess disguised as a guest who listens to Telemachus speak about the situation
Containers filled with wine and water by the pages
Containers carried by maids to distribute bread
Young man speaking about his father's fate and questioning the disguised Minerva about her identity and origins
Homeland where Telemachus hopes his father will return, destination where the visitor arrived
Telemachus's father who has fallen on an ill fate and whose bones may be rotting in wilderness or grinding to powder in surf
Goddess disguised as Mentes who answers Telemachus's questions about her identity
Identity assumed by Minerva, son of Anchialus and King of the Taphians
Father of Mentes, as claimed by the disguised Minerva
People ruled by Mentes as their king, according to Minerva's disguise
Destination where Mentes claims to be bound on his voyage
Destination where Mentes is bound with a cargo of iron to trade for copper
Harbour where Mentes' ship lies, located off the open country away from the town
Wooded mountain under which the harbour Rheithron is situated
Old man who was friends with Mentes' father, lives by himself in the country with an old woman to care for him, works in his vineyard
Trader who speaks to Telemachus, claims friendship between their fathers, brings news about Ulysses
Telemachus' father who is likely on a sea-girt island or prisoner among savages, described as a man of great resource
Caretaker who looks after Laertes and prepares his meals when he returns from his vineyard
People who may be detaining Ulysses against his will as a prisoner
Vessel belonging to Mentes that lies in the harbour Rheithron, used for trading cargo
Agricultural area where Laertes works and tends to his vines
Man of great resource who could escape even from iron chains, close friend of Mentes before sailing to Troy, father of Telemachus and most ill-starred man under heaven
Son who resembles Ulysses about the head and eyes, told by his mother he is Ulysses' son but wishes for a father who grew old on his own estates
Destination where Ulysses sailed along with the flower of all the Argives
Greek warriors, the flower of whom went to Troy along with Ulysses
Close friend of Ulysses before he sailed to Troy, notices Telemachus's resemblance to his father
Mother of Telemachus who tells him he is son to Ulysses
Goddess disguised as Mentes who speaks about Telemachus's race and asks about the feasting
Son who speaks about his father's disappearance and the current state of his house, inherits nothing but dismay
Missing father who was hidden away by the gods, spirited away by storm-winds without leaving a trace
People behaving atrociously and making riot over the whole house, enough to disgust any respectable person
Divine beings who in their displeasure have willed Ulysses to be hidden away more closely than any mortal man
Place where Ulysses could have fallen with his men in battle
Greek people who would have built a mound over Ulysses' ashes if he had died at Troy
Natural forces that have spirited Ulysses away to an unknown location
Young man whose father is lost and whose house is being eaten up by suitors, facing sorrows laid upon him by heaven
Island from which chiefs come to court Telemachus's mother
Island from which chiefs come to court Telemachus's mother
Woodland island from which chiefs come to court Telemachus's mother
Island where the principal men are eating up Telemachus's house under pretext of courting his mother
Leaders from various islands who are eating up Telemachus's house under pretext of paying court to his mother
Telemachus's mother who will neither refuse to marry nor bring matters to an end, being courted by suitors
Rascally men making havoc of Telemachus's estate, described as those Ulysses would lay hands about
Goddess who exclaims about wanting Ulysses home and recalls when he was in their house drinking and making merry
Missing father who Minerva knew when he was drinking and making merry, went to Ephyra to beg poison for his arrows
Piece of armor that Minerva suggests giving to Ulysses
Defensive weapon that Minerva suggests giving to Ulysses
Spear weapons that Minerva suggests giving to Ulysses, specifically a couple of them
Place where Ulysses went to beg poison for his arrows from Ilus
Son of Mermerus who feared the ever-living gods and would not give Ulysses poison
Father of Ilus
Speaker who mentions his father was fond of Ulysses and gave him poison, advises Telemachus about dealing with suitors
Man who received poison from Mentes' father, whose return would give suitors a short shrift and sorry wedding
Men who will have a short shrift and sorry wedding if Ulysses returns, advised to take themselves off to their own places
Young man being advised to call assembly, get rid of suitors, and go in quest of his missing father
Heroes whom Telemachus is advised to call in assembly to lay his case before them
Telemachus's mother whose mind may be set on marrying again, advised to go back to her father
Man who would find Penelope a husband and provide marriage gifts for his dear daughter
Best vessel that Telemachus is advised to take with a crew of twenty men to search for his father
Twenty men that Telemachus should take with him on the ship to quest for his father
First destination where Telemachus should go to ask Nestor about his father
Person in Pylos whom Telemachus should ask about his father's whereabouts
Second destination where Telemachus should visit Menelaus
Person in Sparta who got home last of all the Achaeans and should be visited by Telemachus
Greek warriors of whom Menelaus was the last to get home
Young man being advised to visit Pylos and Sparta, too old to plead infancy, compared to Orestes
Men making waste in Telemachus's house who should be killed by fair means or foul
Person whose praises are being sung for having killed his father's murderer Aegisthus
Murderer of Orestes' father who was killed by Orestes
Speaker who must go back to his ship and crew, giving advice to Telemachus
Vessel that Mentes must return to
Group of people waiting for Mentes who will be impatient if kept waiting longer
Young man who speaks kindly to the stranger, offers hospitality including a bath and present, receives courage and thinks more about his father
Goddess disguised as a stranger who declines to stay longer, promises to return for a present, flies away like a bird and gives Telemachus courage
Keepsake of great beauty and value that Telemachus offers to give, such as only dear friends give to one another
Refreshment that Telemachus offers to the stranger before departure
Creature that Minerva resembles when she flies away into the air
Telemachus's father whom he thinks about more than ever after Minerva's visit
Young man who realized the stranger had been a god and went straight to where the suitors were sitting
Group of men sitting and listening to Phemius sing, drinking wine
Singer who was telling the sad tale of the return from Troy and the ills Minerva laid upon the Achaeans
Place from which there was a sad tale of return that Phemius was singing about
Goddess who had laid ills upon the Achaeans according to Phemius's song
Greek people upon whom Minerva had laid ills according to the song
Daughter of Icarius who heard the song from upstairs, came down attended by handmaids, stood by bearing posts with a veil before her face, weeping bitterly
Father of Penelope
Two female servants who attended Penelope when she came downstairs
Structural supports for the roof of the cloisters where Penelope stood
Covering that Penelope held before her face while weeping
Penelope's lost husband whom she mourns without ceasing, whose name was great over all Hellas and middle Argos
Region where Ulysses's name was great
Region where Ulysses's name was great
Son who answers his mother, tells her to let the bard sing, claims to be master of the house and that speech is man's matter
Mother who is told by Telemachus to busy herself with daily duties, goes back into house wondering and mourns her husband until sleep comes
Singer who Telemachus defends, saying bards don't make the ills they sing of
God who makes the ills that bards sing of and sends weal or woe upon mankind according to his pleasure
People whose ill-fated return from Troy the bard sings about
Man who never came back from Troy, mourned by Penelope as her dear husband
Place from which Ulysses and many others never returned
Daily duty tool that Telemachus tells his mother to busy herself with
Daily duty tool for spinning that Telemachus mentions to his mother
People whose ordering Telemachus tells his mother to attend to
Female servants who accompany Penelope upstairs to her room
Goddess who sheds sweet sleep over Penelope's eyes while she mourns
Men who were clamorous throughout the covered cloisters and prayed
Shameless and insolent men who were clamorous in the covered cloisters, each praying to be Penelope's bed fellow, who feast at Telemachus's expense
Young man who speaks boldly to the suitors, calls them shameless and insolent, gives them formal notice to depart, claims he will be chief in Ithaca
Man with a divine voice who sings, praised by Telemachus for his rare vocal talent
God who Telemachus says shall reckon with the suitors in full if they persist in their behavior
Son of Eupeithes who responds to Telemachus, marvels at his boldness, suggests the gods have given him lessons in bluster and tall talking
Father of Antinous
Place where Telemachus's father was chief before him and where Telemachus claims he will be chief
Telemachus's father who was previously chief in Ithaca, referenced as "your father" by Antinous
Young man who aspires to be chief and claims he will rule in his own house over those whom Ulysses won for him, states his father is dead
Dead father of Telemachus who won people for his son to rule over
Place where there are many great men both old and young, where no one should do violence or rob while there is a man there
Son of Polybus who speaks to Telemachus about leadership and asks about the stranger
Father of Eurymachus
Well-to-do man who hurried off suddenly before the suitors could get to know him, possibly brought news about Telemachus's father's return
Young man who states his father is dead, puts no faith in rumors, knows in his heart the stranger was a goddess, has a room high up in a tower
Telemachus's dead father who was an old friend of Mentes
Telemachus's mother who sometimes sends for a soothsayer and questions him
Person whom Penelope sometimes sends for and questions, whose prophecies Telemachus gives no heed
Son of Anchialus, chief of the Taphians, old friend of Ulysses, identity claimed by the stranger
Father of Mentes
People ruled by Mentes as their chief
Goddess who Telemachus knew in his heart had been the stranger
Men who returned to singing and dancing until evening, then went home to bed in their own abodes
High structure where Telemachus's room is located, looking onto the outer court
Area that Telemachus's tower room looks onto
Good old woman, daughter of Ops, who went before Telemachus with blazing torches
Father of Euryclea, son of Pisenor
Grandfather of Euryclea, father of Ops
Blazing implements carried by Euryclea to light the way
Person who bought Euryclea with his own money when she was young, gave the worth of twenty oxen for her
Man who had a wedded wife and feared her resentment, so did not take Euryclea to his bed despite respecting her
Wedded wife of Laertes whose resentment he feared regarding Euryclea
Good old woman who lighted Telemachus to his room, loved him better than other women in the house, had nursed him as a baby, folded his shirt and hung it up
Young man who was nursed by Euryclea as a baby, went to his bedroom, took off his shirt, lay covered with woollen fleece thinking of his voyage
Telemachus's room where he sat on the bed and slept
Furniture where Telemachus sat and later lay covered with woollen fleece
Garment that Telemachus took off and gave to Euryclea to fold and hang up
Object by the bedside where Euryclea hung Telemachus's shirt
Device used by Euryclea to pull the door closed
Item used by Euryclea to draw the bolt home on the door
Covering under which Telemachus lay while thinking all night
Goddess who had given counsel to Telemachus about his intended voyage
